results.title: Combination of sildenafil and simvastatin ameliorates monocrotaline-induced pulmonary hypertension in rats.
results.text_hl: @CHEMICAL_Sildenafil_Citrate @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000068677 @@@Sildenafil@@@, a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor, and @<m>CHEMICAL_Simvastatin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D019821 @@@simvastatin@@@, a @CHEMICAL_Cholesterol @CHEMICAL_MESH:D002784 @@@cholesterol@@@ lowering drug, both have therapeutic effects on @<m>DISEASE_Phenylketonurias</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D010661 @@@PAH@@@; however, the combination of these drugs has not been tested in the treatment of @<m>DISEASE_Phenylketonurias</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D010661 @@@PAH@@@.

citations.NLM: Kuang T, Wang J, Pang B, Huang X, Burg ED, Yuan JX, Wang C. Combination of sildenafil and simvastatin ameliorates monocrotaline-induced pulmonary hypertension in rats. Pulm Pharmacol Ther. 2010 Oct;23(5):456-64. PMID: 20188205
citations.BibTeX: @article{20188205, title={Combination of sildenafil and simvastatin ameliorates monocrotaline-induced pulmonary hypertension in rats.}, author={Kuang T and Wang J and Pang B and Huang X and Burg ED and Yuan JX and Wang C}, journal={Pulm Pharmacol Ther}, volume={23}, number={5}, pages={456-64}}

results.title: [Expression of connective tissue growth factor and its down-regulation by simvastatin administration in pulmonary hypertensive rats].
results.text_hl: CONCLUSION: The up-regulation of @GENE_CCN2 @GENE_64032 @@@CTGF@@@ gene expression may play an important role in the development of pulmonary vascular remodeling in @<m>DISEASE_Phenylketonurias</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D010661 @@@PAH@@@. @<m>CHEMICAL_Simvastatin</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D019821 @@@Simvastatin@@@ can prevent and, to some extent, reverse the vascular remodeling via down-regulation of @GENE_CCN2 @GENE_64032 @@@CTGF@@@ gene expression.

citations.NLM: Liu B, Wang XM, Zhou TF, Hua YM, Liu HM, Wei L, Qiao LN, Wang XQ, Zhao SS, Shi K. [Expression of connective tissue growth factor and its down-regulation by simvastatin administration in pulmonary hypertensive rats]. Zhonghua Er Ke Za Zhi. 2008 May;46(5):359-65. PMID: 19099753
